targetAudience: Build workout consistency in 30 days. Perfect for fitness beginners and those restarting after a break.
scientificRationale: The hardest part of fitness isn't the workout—it's showing up consistently. Research shows that 30 days of regular exercise creates enough positive feedback (energy, mood, strength gains) to motivate continuation. By committing to 20-30 minute workouts 4-5x/week for 30 days, you build the habit infrastructure that makes long-term fitness sustainable. This is the gateway to becoming someone who works out.

challengeFAQs.question: Is 30 days enough to see real results?
challengeFAQs.answer: Yes. 30 days of consistent training produces measurable strength gains (2-3x capacity in pushups/sit-ups), visible muscle definition, improved energy and mood. While 66 days is better for permanent habit automation, 30 days creates enough momentum and results to motivate continued training. 87% of NooLife 30-day finishers continue beyond 30 days.

challengeFAQs.question: I'm completely out of shape. Can I do this?
challengeFAQs.answer: Yes. Start with modified exercises (knee pushups instead of full pushups, crunches instead of full sit-ups). NooLife personalizes your plan based on Day 1 baseline. If you can only do 5 pushups, your plan starts there and builds incrementally. The key is consistency, not starting strength.

challengeFAQs.question: Do I need a gym membership?
challengeFAQs.answer: No. This challenge is designed for bodyweight training (pushups, sit-ups, squats, lunges). You can do everything at home or in a park. Gym access adds variety but isn't required. NooLife tracks all movements—bodyweight, resistance bands, or gym equipment.

challengeFAQs.question: What if I miss a workout?
challengeFAQs.answer: Get back on track immediately. Your streak resets, but progress doesn't zero out. Missing one workout shouldn't become two. The goal is 16-20 workouts in 30 days, not perfection. Life happens—NooLife tracks your bounce-back and cumulative improvements.

challengeFAQs.question: Should I workout when I'm sore?
challengeFAQs.answer: Yes, but adjust intensity. Light movement helps recovery (active recovery). If you're extremely sore, do a lighter workout (fewer reps, simpler exercises). Sitting on the couch makes soreness worse. Consistency > intensity. Soreness peaks around Day 3-5 and fades by Day 10-12.
